deliberation: Formulaic prophetic introduction. Considered whether "the word ... came" is merely technical or retains metaphorical force. Treated the movement verb with an abstract subject ("word") as a conventional metaphor/idiom for revelation.

instances.hebrew_text: הָיָה הַדָּבָר הַזֶּה אֶל־יִרְמְיָהוּ מֵאֵת יְהוָה
instances.english_text: this word came to Jeremiah from GOD
vehicle: a 'word' that comes/arrives like a visitor
ground: revelation originates from God and reaches the prophet with initiative and direction
posture: prophetic narrator's formal description of inspiration
instances.explanation: The abstract 'word' is depicted as something that 'comes' to Jeremiah, using movement imagery for an act of revelation. This is a conventional metaphor/idiom for prophetic inspiration.

deliberation: Instruction to take a physical scroll and write past prophecies. Expressions like 'all the words that I have spoken' are straightforward. No metaphor, simile, personification, or idiom beyond normal lexical usage.

Looked for figurative expressions in 'House of Judah', 'evil way', and 'turn back'. 'House of Judah' is a standard collective designation (metonymy). 'Turn back from his evil way' uses way/path as a metaphor for moral conduct.

ground: the people form a single entity like members of one household under one roof and head
instances.explanation: A 'house' stands metonymically for the people belonging to it. 'House of Judah' refers to Judah’s population as one corporate entity, not to a literal building.

instances.english_text: they will turn back, each from his evil way
vehicle: a road/way that one walks on
ground: behavior has direction and can be continued or reversed like walking on a path
instances.explanation: A person's behavior is conceptualized as a 'way' or path, and repentance as 'turning back' from that path. This is a standard biblical metaphor for moral change.

deliberation: Plain narration of dictation and writing. 'Words of YHWH' simply labels divine speech recorded on a scroll. No particular figurative construal beyond normal language.
Jeremiah says he is 'restrained' and cannot go to the temple—likely literal restriction (confinement or ban). No clear metaphor or idiom beyond straightforward physical limitation.

Instruction to read in the scroll 'in the ears' of the people. The 'ears' expression is normal Hebrew for 'in the hearing of' and functions as a literal bodily reference for hearing. Did not treat as marked figurative language here.

Considered three expressions: (1) 'their supplication will fall before YHWH', (2) 'turn back from his evil way', (3) 'great is the anger and wrath'. All three employ non-literal imagery: prayer as a falling object, behavior as a path, and wrath as burning/flaring heat.

instances.english_text: Perhaps their entreaty will fall before GOD
vehicle: something or someone that 'falls before' another
ground: earnest supplication is like falling down or casting oneself before a superior, coming into their presence for mercy
social dynamics of approach to power
posture: hopeful conditional appeal to divine mercy
instances.explanation: The supplication is depicted as 'falling' before YHWH, picturing prayer as a prostrate, falling entity entering God's presence. This is an idiomatic metaphor for an appeal being presented and potentially accepted.

instances.english_text: if they turn back, each from his wicked way
vehicle: a road/way that one travels on
ground: conduct is like a path whose direction can be reversed; repentance is a literal 'turning back' from a course
posture: appeal to change behavior to avert judgment
instances.explanation: As in v.3, behavior is conceptualized as a 'way' and repentance as turning back from that path. This is a conventional moral metaphor.

instances.english_text: For great is the anger and wrath with which GOD has threatened this people
target: GOD's disposition toward the people in judgment
ground: anger is like burning heat and flared nostrils in humans—intense, hot, and dangerous; this image is applied to God's judgment
mapping physical reactions onto emotional/judicial states
instances.explanation: The Hebrew uses body-part and heat terms (nose/anger, heat/wrath) for God's judgment. This is an anthropopathic metaphor: divine wrath portrayed in terms of human physical anger and burning heat.

deliberation: Straightforward report that Baruch obeyed and read the words. No non-literal phrasing beyond normal attributions of speech.
Narrative of a fast proclaimed before YHWH in Jerusalem. Expressions like 'called a fast' and 'before YHWH' are cultic but literal. No marked figurative structures.
Detailed spatial description of Baruch’s location in the temple complex while reading. All terms appear to be literal architectural references.

Micaiah 'heard all the words of YHWH from the scroll.' Here the words of YHWH are literally those written in the scroll and read aloud. No special metaphor beyond normal terminology for written prophecy.
Plain description of Micaiah going down to the king’s house and listing officials. No figurative language detected.
Report that Micaiah told the officials what he heard as Baruch read to the people. Language is straightforward.
Officials send for Baruch with the scroll. The language of taking the scroll 'in your hand' and coming is literal. No evident figurative devices.
Request to 'sit and read in our ears' is conventional for 'read for us to hear' and here functions literally. No distinctive figurative imagery.
The officials 'feared, each to his neighbor.' This depicts mutual fear and consultation but does not hinge on metaphor; it is a literal emotional reaction. No strong figurative expression.
They ask Baruch how he wrote the words. Straightforward inquiry with no figurative phrasing.
Baruch explains that Jeremiah recited and he wrote in ink on the scroll. Purely literal description of the writing process.
Officials urge Baruch and Jeremiah to hide and not reveal their location. Language of hiding is literal in context of political danger.
They store the scroll and report matters to the king. Verbs 'deposit' and 'tell' are literal here. No figurative constructions.
Jehudi fetches and reads the scroll. Again this is straightforward narrative without figurative language.
Description of the setting: the king sitting in the winter house with a fire burning. All elements are literal physical details.

The king cuts the scroll and throws it into the fire until it is consumed. Destruction of the scroll is literal; fire and knife are not symbolic here but actual instruments. No figurative device singled out.

The verse contrasts their lack of fear with their failure to 'tear their garments'. Tearing garments is a cultural symbolic act for grief/repentance and thus functions idiomatically/metonymically for inner reaction.

instances.english_text: and [they] did not tear their garments
target: their inner grief, fear, or repentance
ground: in that culture, tearing one's clothes is a visible sign of intense grief or repentance; clothing represents the self's status
use of physical signs to express emotion
instances.explanation: Rending garments is an idiomatic symbolic act for mourning or repentance. By saying they did not tear their garments, the text metonymically indicates their lack of appropriate inner response.

deliberation: Elnathan, Delaiah, and Gemariah 'interceded' (begged) the king not to burn the scroll; he refused to listen. These are standard verbs for pleading and heeding. No clear figurative usage beyond normal.

The king orders the seizure of Baruch and Jeremiah, but 'YHWH hid them'. This reflects divine protection in a concrete way; the hiding is best read as literal concealment effected by God’s providence, not as a metaphorical description.
Repetition of the prophetic formula 'the word of YHWH came to Jeremiah' after the burning of the scroll. As in v.1, this uses movement language for an act of revelation.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to Jeremiah
ground: God initiates contact; revelation approaches the prophet like a visitor or message arriving from outside
posture: formal prophetic introduction of an oracle
instances.explanation: Again the abstract 'word' is portrayed as something that 'comes' to Jeremiah. This conventional prophetic idiom relies on a movement metaphor for the reception of God’s message.

deliberation: Command to take another scroll and rewrite the same words. The description of burning and rewriting is literal, not metaphorical.

Looked at 'destroy this land' and 'cause human and animal to cease from it'. 'Destroy this land' is literal. The paired 'man and beast' is a well-known merism for all living inhabitants in the land, emphasizing total desolation.

instances.english_text: and cause human and animal to cease from it
target: all life and inhabitants in the land
population and livestock as a whole
vehicle: 'man and beast' as two poles of living creatures
ground: naming the main categories of inhabitants (humans and domestic animals) conveys total depopulation and devastation
instances.explanation: The phrase 'man and beast' functions as a merism, evoking all kinds of living beings in the land to stress complete desolation, not just those two categories in isolation.

deliberation: Considered two expressions: (1) 'sitting on the throne of David' as a symbolic designation of ruling in the Davidic line (metonymy), and (2) the corpse thrown out to 'the heat by day and the frost by night', which uses environmental extremes as a merism for total, ongoing exposure and disgrace.

instances.english_text: He shall not have any of his line sitting on the throne of David
vehicle: the 'throne of David' and sitting upon it
ground: to sit on a royal throne is to hold kingship; the throne stands for the institution of Davidic rule
posture: annulment of Davidic succession through Jehoiakim
instances.explanation: The 'throne of David' metonymically represents the Davidic kingship. Saying no descendant will sit on it declares the end of his dynastic rule.

instances.hebrew_text: וְנִבְלָתוֹ תִּהְיֶה מֻשְׁלֶכֶת לַחֹרֶב בַּיּוֹם וְלַקֶּרַח בַּלָּיְלָה
instances.english_text: and his own corpse shall be left exposed to the heat by day and the cold by night
vehicle: a corpse thrown out to unshielded heat and frost day and night
ground: lack of burial and protection signifies utter disgrace; day/night heat/cold cover the whole cycle, implying ongoing humiliation
shame expressed via unrelieved environmental suffering
instances.explanation: While Jehoiakim’s body might literally be unburied, the pairing of 'heat by day and frost by night' forms a meristic image of constant exposure, emphasizing total dishonor and abandonment.

deliberation: Considered 'I will visit upon him ... their iniquity' and 'I will bring upon them all the evil.' 'Visit upon' is a standard judicial idiom/metaphor for punishing, portraying judgment as a visit or inspection.

instances.english_text: And I will punish him and his offspring and his courtiers for their iniquity (literally: I will visit upon him ... their iniquity)
target: Jehoiakim, his descendants, and servants as offenders
vehicle: a 'visit' or inspection imposed upon them
ground: a superior's visit entails scrutiny and consequences; punishment is pictured as God coming to them to reckon with their guilt
instances.explanation: The idiom 'to visit upon' uses the metaphor of a visit or official inspection to depict God’s act of punishing their iniquity.

deliberation: Description of taking another scroll, rewriting, and adding many similar words. All described actions are literal. No figurative language detected.
